text:
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins. This means telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know, that you are not at home. This made people think about the problems of sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because it might bring us money or fame. So, we share personal stories and photos online. But later, we might find out that this can be dangerous and confusing.
But don't worry, there is hope. A long time ago, some people started using the internet in new ways. They were the first bloggers. They shared their lives online and learned from their mistakes. We can learn from them too. In 1994, a student named Justin Hall started sharing his life on the internet. He wrote about everything and posted photos. People liked reading about his life. But one day, he had to stop because it caused problems in his personal life. He learned that sharing too much can make people not trust you.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong had a blog where she sometimes wrote about her job. One day, someone at her work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But Heather's story ended well. She got married, started writing about her family, and became a successful "mommy blogger." She learned to share carefully online.
The lesson here is that the internet lets us say anything, but we should be careful about what we share.

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we don't understand. Scientists usually agree that we don't know everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the film and called it "atrocious" and "dangerous." 
At first, the film seemed harmless. It showed scientists saying that new discoveries make the universe seem stranger than we thought. But then, the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being changed by thoughts. A Japanese researcher said that the shape of a water molecule could change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by happy people and looking bad after being around unhappy people. Some people found this evidence convincing, but many scientists did not. They wanted more proof.
The film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that water molecules have properties because of a form of energy that seems to come from nowhere. This energy is linked to a force that is making the universe expand. This is not just based on pictures; it comes from years of research. Scientists have discovered that the universe is made of unknown matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called "dark energy."
Other discoveries are also amazing. Neuroscientists found that our brain takes about half a second to understand what we see, but we don't notice this delay. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans first lived and why they moved to other places. Some scientists believe there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.
Science is not finished. We are learning that many natural things cannot be fully understood. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show limits to what we can know. Some physicists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is best described in one word: incredible.

I find writing novels difficult, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, and writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important to me. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves. In the garden, flowers bloom, and bees and butterflies come. This shows how seasons change. Since I started writing, I switch between novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. After finishing short stories, I want to write a novel. I never write both at the same time. Writing novels and short stories might use different parts of the brain, so I need time to change from one to the other. I started with two short novels in 1975, and then I wrote short stories from 1984 to 1985. I didn't know much about writing short stories then, so it was hard, but I remember it well. Writing short stories made my fictional world bigger. Readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story book, Tales from Abroad. Writing short stories is nice because they don't take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story good (though I can revise it many times). It's not like writing a novel, which takes a year or two and is very tiring. With short stories, you can finish quickly. Writing a novel feels like it takes forever, and I sometimes wonder if I will finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change. You can make a short story from small things – an idea, a word, or an image. It's like jazz music, where the story goes where it wants. If a short story doesn't work, it's okay. Not every story is great, even for famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. This makes me feel better. You can learn from mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from my short stories. Short stories are like a test for me as a novelist. It's hard to try new things in a novel, so short stories help me. My short stories are like shadows or footprints I leave behind. I remember each one and how I felt when I wrote it. Short stories show my feelings, and I like sharing them with my readers.

Science is a big part of our lives. It helps us understand the world and can cure diseases. Science can make life easier, but it can also be dangerous if not understood well. Scientists try to learn about everything, from tiny atoms to the huge universe. Science changes a lot because new ideas come and old ones go. Sometimes, new ideas are not accepted at first, but later they become important. Scientists often disagree, but this helps science grow.
Science is not just about making things like non-stick pans. It is about big ideas that change how we think. Science is always changing. One scientist might prove another scientist wrong. This usually does not change our daily lives, but sometimes it changes what we believe. For example, in the past, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Now, we know it is more complex.
Some people think science cannot explain everything, but it helps us understand more and more. Famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein helped us learn a lot. Science sometimes makes mistakes, but it keeps moving forward. In the past, people thought there was nothing new to learn in physics, but then many new things were discovered, like X-rays and black holes.
Science is important for our future. We have learned to control some parts of nature, but we must be careful not to harm it. Everyone should understand science because it affects our lives and the world our children will live in. Science helps us plan for the future, and it is important for everyone, not just scientists or philosophers. The choices we make in science can affect our health, money, and even life on Earth.

'Around 2015, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question if ebooks would be important in the future. One publishing boss said that the excitement about ebooks made his company invest too much and forget how important printed books are. Even though digital and print books can both exist, people still ask if ebooks will replace printed books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting each other? This is not just about books. It shows how we feel excited and scared about new things. In my research, I found that people often think new technology will replace old ones. For example, when TV was invented, people thought radio would disappear, but radio survived by being used in cars and other places. The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times with movies, radio, TV, and smartphones. Some people think losing books would be bad for culture, while others think ebooks are better. This idea comes up when new technology appears because it shows our hopes and fears about change. We have strong feelings about things like books, TVs, and computers because they are part of our lives. When new technology like e-readers comes, it changes our connection with these things. We might miss what we used to have. That's why people like old things, like vinyl records or silent movies, when new things come. E-readers made people appreciate old books more, even their smell. This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of losing old things will always be interesting because it shows how technology changes us and how we don't like change. We use stories about endings to understand change. The story of books disappearing shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing what we know and love.'

'Almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how some of the smartest people in the last four hundred years did their best work. I wanted to know how they found time each day to be creative and productive. By writing about their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I hoped to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that they were like us, with habits and routines. The French food expert Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, ‘Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.’ I say, ‘Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.’ This book is about the daily life of creative people, not their work. It’s also personal. The writer John Cheever thought that even a business letter shows something about you – isn’t that true? In my book, I think about questions I have in my own life: How do you do creative work and also make money? Is it better to work on a project all at once or a little each day? When there isn’t enough time, do you give up things like sleep or a clean house, or do you learn to do more in less time? I don’t have all the answers, but I show how different successful people faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions; how your work habits affect your work, and the other way around. The book is called Daily Rituals, but it’s really about routines. A routine can seem boring, but it can help you use your time, energy, and optimism well. A good routine helps you focus and not be controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot; by forming good habits, he said, we can ‘free our minds to do more interesting things.’ Ironically, James himself often procrastinated and couldn’t stick to a schedule. This book started because I was procrastinating. One Sunday, I was alone at the architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was cleaning my desk and making coffee. I’m a ‘morning person’ and can focus well in the morning but not after lunch. That afternoon, I looked online for other writers’ work schedules. I found many and thought someone should collect these stories – so I started the Daily Routines blog and now this book. The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine articles, and newspapers. For the book, I collected more stories and did more research, but kept the short and varied voices that made the blog interesting. I let my subjects speak for themselves with quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t be possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which can also guide you to more reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, decided they could not go on holiday to Spain because of high interest rates. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. This made him want to become a palaeontologist. At university, he decided he wanted to study the very early life forms, not dinosaurs. He worked hard on his studies and finished his doctoral thesis. He worried about finding a job, but he believed in himself. 
When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied. On the day of the interview, the professor who was supposed to help another candidate had an accident and could not attend. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job instead. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he later learned it was because of the professors' disagreement. 
Howard liked his job because he could plan his work. But he knew that life could be unpredictable. One day, his briefcase with important lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. He was upset but went back to the college and had coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils there. This was a big opportunity for him. He changed his plans to visit the museum in Nairobi, which would help his career. 
*An ammonite is a type of fossil.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University in the UK. He studies how our senses work together to change the way we taste food. At home, he even has ice cream made from bee larvae, which tastes a bit like nuts and flowers. Spence and his team are trying to make eating bugs more normal. They study how things like who we eat with, how food looks, and even background noise can change how food tastes.
Spence wrote a book called "The Perfect Meal" with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman. It has many interesting facts about eating. For example, the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their food the most. Also, we eat more when we are with other people.
Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and not very high-tech. He works with cooks who can't pay for research themselves. His work is often paid for by big food companies. These companies want to reduce salt and sugar in their products without people noticing. They do it slowly so customers don't taste the change.
Spence also works with famous chefs like Heston Blumenthal. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea" that uses sound to change how food tastes. Spence found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon use music to make food taste better for passengers.
At home, Spence has fun dinner parties. Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used colored lights and sounds to see how it changed the taste of drinks. For Spence, home and work are closely connected.

Our brains are very busy today. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important. We also do more things ourselves now. For example, we book our own flights and find things in shops without help. We try to do many things at once, like work, family, hobbies, and watching TV, with the help of our smartphones. But there is a problem. We think we can do many things at the same time, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a brain expert, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we multitask, we switch quickly from one thing to another, and this makes us less efficient. Multitasking can make us stressed and confused. It also makes our brains want more new things to look at. The part of the brain that helps us focus is easily distracted by new things. Just having the chance to multitask can make us perform worse. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. Multitasking can be worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, another brain expert, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part of the brain that helps remember facts better. Multitasking also means making many decisions, which is hard for our brains. Even small decisions can make us tired and lead to bad choices. Many people say email is a big problem because of the large number of messages. A colleague's son said his father just answers emails all day, which is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do this and finish other tasks.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think these questions were important. Scientists studied animal actions and their results, but not their feelings. They thought animals did not have feelings or morals. But now, this is changing. Scientists are starting to study animal emotions, like in bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens. This has led to books like "Wild Justice" by Mark Bekoff and "Do Fish Feel Pain?" by Victoria Braithwaite. These studies have started a debate: do animals have feelings and a sense of right and wrong? 
In one study, cows had to open a gate to get food. Cows that opened the gate themselves were happier than those that needed help. This suggests cows like solving problems. What does this mean for eating beef? Some people, like Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, think we should stop eating meat. He believes this is a big change in how we think about animals, like when slavery ended. Professor Aubrey Manning thinks we should rethink how smart animals are. He says animals have a simpler way of thinking than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop thinking animals are like humans. 
The main issue is not just science or morals, but philosophy. It is hard to define what consciousness is. Can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages, and the other had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt sad about life. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, believes we will one day see animals like we see racism now. He says we cannot support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger. 
If Balcombe was the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning wrote a book about animal behavior. He says our views on animals are changing. In the past, people thought animals were like humans, then they thought the opposite. Now, we are changing again. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear better. Adrian West, a research director, says that people think arguments help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and think deeply. We see a lot of information and opinions, which can make it hard to think clearly. More data does not always mean more knowledge or better decisions. Reading books has decreased, and some people, like Patricia Greenfield, think this affects our critical thinking. We focus more on quick media and doing many things at once instead of concentrating on one thing. We don't know exactly how technology affects thinking, but it changes how we think. Computers and the internet can be good or bad for thinking, depending on how we use them. Reading helps us think and imagine, while visual media like video games and TV do not. However, visual media can improve some information processing. Many young people do not use their full potential because of this. How we see technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games and learning are a big part of this discussion. James Paul Gee, a professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and thinking skills. They let people explore ideas in a way that is like the real world. In the digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking.

Matthew Crawford is a writer and a motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about why working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how to live in the modern world. He got the idea when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. He thinks these ads make it hard for us to focus on what we want to think about. 
Crawford says that because of these distractions, we don't talk to strangers as much. We see the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can control what we want. Many people feel the same way. For example, some office workers complain about emails but still check them all the time. Studies show that just seeing a phone can make us lose focus.
Crawford believes that technology makes us think more about ourselves. We often choose to send texts instead of talking to people. This can make us lose real connections with others. He gives an example of a gym where people used to share music, but now everyone listens to their own music with earphones. This change makes the gym less social.
Crawford has two ideas to help. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. Second, we should do activities that make us focus on real things, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us connect with the world and other people. They also help us focus better and feel more satisfied.

"‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. But for me, as a philosopher, it is a bit harder to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound like you think you know more than others. But philosophers are just like everyone else. People think philosophers judge others and love thinking. A Greek philosopher, Aristotle, said thinking is the best way to live. Another philosopher, Socrates, said we should think about our lives to make them better. This does not mean reading many books. It means looking at our daily lives to see if they are good. Philosophy should help us live better lives. 
Today, philosophy in universities is often far from real life. Philosophers write in expensive journals that most people cannot read. This makes philosophy seem hard to understand. Many philosophers do not try to change this. They focus on small, difficult topics. This is not good. Philosophy should be part of everyday life. 
I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I study ethics, which is about right and wrong actions. But ethics is more than just rules and laws. It looks at if things like downloading movies illegally are wrong. It also looks at bigger ideas like responsibility and art. Philosophy helps us think about our actions and beliefs. By doing this, we can help everyone live better."

People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and others, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. In the past, talking about food was not as important as talking about other big ideas. Sometimes, when philosophers talked about eating, they used it to explain other things, like learning. Sometimes, they talked about food, but it was really about other ideas. An old Greek philosopher named Epicurus talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain in many ways. But now, people think of him as someone who loved eating and drinking. We see his name in restaurants and food shops because they think it will help them sell more. Food is very social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with people around us. We eat with others and get our food from our community. We deal with food more than anything else, so it is a good topic to think about. After food is made, people talk and write about it. But why do some people have a special role in this? One philosopher said that tasting food is not a special skill, but some people are just better at describing it. Most studies about how we see things have not looked much at taste, and this should change. Another part of food is how it looks and feels. We say paintings or music are beautiful, but not food. Some philosophers think food should be talked about like art. But food is eaten and gone, unlike art that stays. There are many questions about what we should eat, like organic or vegetarian. Our choices show what we believe is right. Philosophers ask why we make these choices. Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a duty to their guests because of love and friendship. In restaurants, cooks have duties to their boss and the food. Their kitchens are for trained people, and they work with colleagues, not friends. A recent essay talks about how food can help connect different cultures. We can learn about others by enjoying their food and eating together, which has been important in international meetings. The essay uses fun stories to show this part of food philosophy to everyone.

Rob Daviau is from the US and makes special board games called 'legacy' games. He thought old board games were not fun or challenging anymore. He wanted to make games with a story. He changed a game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices you make stay for the next time you play. You might have to tear cards or change the board. The game has a set number of times you play, and players remember past actions. Daviau also helped make a legacy version of Pandemic, a game where players stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall, where players explore new lands in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century). Making legacy games is hard because designers must think about all player choices. They use testers to see how the game works. Jaime Barriga tested SeaFall and said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first but then breaks, and they have to fix it. People did not think legacy games would be very popular. Daviau thought only a few people would like them. But many players, like Russell Chapman, loved them. He thinks they are exciting and new. Ben Hogg, another fan, likes the adventure in legacy games. He says it's like watching a new movie, not the same one again. Legacy games are like video games and TV shows with episodes. Daviau wanted to write for TV but ended up making games. He likes telling stories in games. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock says making a legacy game is like writing a book. You need to know how it starts and ends. Daviau is happy to see others use his idea but thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who works for the company that made SeaFall, thinks legacy games change how we see board games.

'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People like stories about animals escaping, like rats and llamas, because they think animals are like us. Octopuses are very smart, even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and play in a smart way. Some people think it is not scientific to say animals are like humans, but Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, says it is important to see the human-like traits in animals. He calls it 'anthropodenial' when people do not see these traits. Animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval times, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. In the 20th century, people started to see animals as machines that respond to rewards and punishments. This was also a time when humans were destroying animal habitats and not caring for animal welfare. But now, de Waal believes we are starting to understand animal intelligence better. He says the best tests for animal intelligence consider the animal's special skills. For example, squirrels are good at remembering where they hide nuts, even if they are not good at human memory tasks. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not smart because we cannot change our skin color. De Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows that stories like this help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset. A video of this experiment convinced many people that animals can feel envy. This shows how our minds work in interesting ways.'

Robots were once just in science fiction stories, but now they are becoming very important in our world. Robots have been used in car factories for many years, but soon they will be used in many other jobs too. Many people think robots will do most of the work humans do now in the next 50 years. However, most people also think their own jobs will still be the same. This is not true. All jobs will change because of robots.
For example, an Australian company made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than two people can do in a day. In San Francisco, a robot named Tally helps in supermarkets by checking if products are on the shelves and priced correctly.
Some people say robots will create new jobs for people who can fix and program them. But others worry that robots will take away jobs that need people skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs. He says that soon, many robots will be able to work with humans safely. Big companies will have special managers for robots, and governments will make new rules for them.
In five years, people working with robots will earn more money, but there will not be enough skilled workers for all the jobs. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills because they cannot do the same job forever. New robots will also be made for homes and will be more advanced than ever before.
This change is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. Many jobs are at risk, so education is important to prepare for the future with robots. Countries need more people studying science, technology, engineering, and maths to stay competitive.

George Mallory, a famous mountain climber, was once asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He answered, "Because it's there." Many people wonder why someone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams. It shows that climbing can be about adventure and fun. 
In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay about climbing. He said there are seven different types of climbing, like climbing small rocks or big mountains. Each type has its own rules. The way you climb depends on these rules. This idea is now very popular among climbers.
Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. But sometimes, climbing can feel limiting, like when you are stuck in a tent during a storm. This is a bit of a puzzle, but some people think that having fewer choices can make life simpler and more free.
Another climber, Joe Fitschen, thinks we should ask, "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our nature. We like to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it's risky. This is part of who we are.
Brian Treanor, a US academic, says climbing can help us develop good qualities like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these are important in today's world. Climbing can help us grow and live better lives.
Some climbers believe that climbing without help from others or technology is more challenging and deserves more respect. Ebert and Robinson, two expert climbers, said that climbing alone is harder and riskier. This idea caused some debate because it might encourage dangerous climbing.
Climbing can also be about being in the moment and focusing on the climb. This is similar to Zen philosophy, which teaches people to find peace in their minds. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel was very important in classical music. He was a serious and smart person who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw that he could be fun, but he did not show this in his concerts. He was always studying, traveling, and performing. 
Then, a few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not think it was a good idea. He had not taught many students before. He said, ‘You don’t need a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play and was very impressed. Kit played very well and remembered all the music. He even gave Brendel a CD of a concert he did, and Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit’s performance was very special.
As Brendel is stopping his public performances, Kit is starting his career. Brendel is careful because he does not want Kit to get tired too quickly. Kit, now 19, is always busy. He learns new languages, studies math, writes computer code, and plays tennis. His mother is always with him. Kit also writes music. Brendel says this is important because writing music helps you understand it better. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. He listens carefully to his own playing and to Brendel’s advice. When Brendel explains something, Kit understands and can do it.
Brendel is careful not to make people expect too much from Kit. He does not like it when newspapers say Kit will be the best pianist of the 21st century. This can be harmful because Kit is still learning. He can play some things very well, but he needs more time and experience for others.
Now, at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I did not want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by the age of 50. When I was 50, I had done most of those things, but I wanted to do more, so I continued. Now, I do not have the strength to play, but I still think about music. It’s a nice new part of my life.’

When I was a child, I thought gardens were always beautiful places. My Grandad's garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down gently to the water. You couldn't reach the river, but you could hear the water and birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – a place to escape and find peace. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old windows, with plastic covering broken glass.
At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn't boring, though. He liked funny things and had favorite phrases like "It's immaterial to me," which means "I don't mind." He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without finishing and became a plumber. He didn't love plumbing; it was just his job. He wasn't very ambitious, but once he and my mom thought about moving to Canada, but it didn't happen. He was good at fixing things at home, like making bookshelves or cupboards.
My parents moved house only once. But my mom liked to change furniture often. One big change was when we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mom thought they were too fancy and took them away. I never got to play the piano. My sister had lessons instead. When I asked my mom why I didn't get lessons, she said, "You'd never have practiced."
I liked going to the river. I could imagine another world there. I would take a fishing net and wear old sandals. I walked along the river, looking for a place to take off my sandals and look for fish. I tried to keep the fish at home, but it didn't work, so I put them back in the river.
I wanted to leave school as soon as I could. One day, my father said, "There's a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it." My dad usually wanted me to be a carpenter, but maybe he thought gardening could be good for me. I think he saw how much I loved plants and flowers, even though he didn't like gardening himself.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am with him. The strong wind from the Atlantic Ocean is very powerful. It feels like it could blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. Lawrence's sheepdog, Tie, comes to us, and Lawrence pets him gently. Even with the strong wind, Lawrence feels comfortable on his island. He is showing me around. He points to the north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets more rain than we do.’ I see rain clouds over Rum's big mountains. ‘Beyond Rum is the island of Soay,’ he says. Suddenly, Lawrence says he needs to move his sheep because rain is coming. We walk down the hill, and he tells me about the island. Muck is three kilometers long and half as wide. The geese eat a lot of grass. The MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. We stop talking to move the sheep. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. Lawrence tells Tie to go to the right, but Tie goes straight into the sheep, causing confusion. Lawrence is disappointed and says, ‘That will never do.’ The dog looks sorry. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son, Colin, takes care of the island cottages. Their daughter, Mary, and her husband, Toby, run the island hotel, Port Mor. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail boats in the summer. ‘They leave the house and come back when they are hungry,’ Mary says. But living on the island has challenges. Electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to come on. The next morning, Mary makes breakfast with a flashlight. I get used to it, even without mobile phone service. Mary tells me, ‘There is mobile reception on the hill. Most people stop using their phones after a few days.’ So I do the same. Life on Muck is different. Today, a boat brings groceries and three musicians. They play music in the island’s tearoom, and everyone enjoys it. That night, by the fire, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. Her father bought a small farm on the Isle of Soay without seeing it. Jenny went to manage it, even though she only had typing skills. I go to bed with the sound of rain and wake up to more rain. But the food is good. Almost all of it comes from the island. Mary sends me to get fresh fish from Sandy Mathers, a fisherman. I bring it back to Mary, and by 7 pm, we have a delicious fish dinner. The next morning, I am supposed to take a ferry to another island. But many ferries have been canceled because of high waves. If my ferry doesn’t come, I will stay on Muck for two more days. Secretly, I hope it doesn’t come.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is taken seriously. It is not easy to get into, but it is growing. Making video games, especially those based on movies, needs many people and a lot of hard work. Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says it is hard to get a big job in big companies. But the industry needs more game designers. Not just the big bosses, but also people who design parts of the game.
How can you get into this industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. He says the best way is to make games. You need to create something to get a job. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. John Field, another expert, agrees but says it is more complicated. Many people want to work in games, but not many have the skills needed. You need to be creative, know technology, have vision, and be able to work on your own.
Can you do it alone? Maybe, but it is hard. A good course in game design can help. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They like all kinds of entertainment and arts. They might have worked a few years after finishing school and then decided to work in games. They are not just fans; they are interested in the future of games. Connections with people in the industry can also help you get ahead.
The idea of video games being just for young boys is old. Now, video games are for everyone. Families play together on consoles. Smartphones have many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. Games are popular with many people and are a great way to learn. There are many opportunities in this big and growing area.

Since I was a child, I always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told my friend what he couldn't do. My friend stopped wanting to play football because of this. I am happy my dad was different. 
When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. The best players practice a lot, even if they have natural talent. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills.
At school, I played many sports like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know education is important, but I only thought about football then. The teachers were good, but I didn't notice at the time. I want my son to have a good education. We try to read him books, but he is too young to sit still. He likes to kick the books around, like me.
At the start of my football career, the manager helped young players like me join the first team. He didn't make a big deal about it, but we knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game, but we lost. A TV presenter said, "You can't win anything with kids." This made us work harder. We believed in ourselves as a team.
I rely on my close friends and family. Having a lot of money can be a problem. People say, "I can't believe you let your mother work." I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car. My family is strong and would not like to be on my payroll. My mum loves her job as a hairdresser, even if she doesn't earn much. I like to use my money to help people around me.
I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off. I want to do things I couldn't do before, like skiing. I can't ski now because if I break a leg, I can't play football, and I wouldn't be insured.

Sam Carter helped us find a place to live at Reef Point. Sam was my dad's agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn't write anything good in Los Angeles, so Sam found us a cheap place to live. Reef Point was quiet in the summer because sea fogs made it cold. People didn't visit much because the road was bad, and a nicer place called La Carmella was nearby. Only people with no money or who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, many people came, and it got busy. My dad was busy writing a script and didn't notice me much. I spent my days on the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We didn't have a dog when we moved to Reef Point, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I gave him water, and my dad didn't mind him much. Rusty loved the beach and often brought me things he found, like shoes or towels, which I had to return to their owners. He also liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. One day, after swimming, we watched surfers. One surfer was really good. She came over and talked to me. She asked why I didn't surf, and I said I didn't have a surfboard or money. She guessed I was British and asked about my dad. I told her he was Rufus Marsh, who wrote "Tall as the Morning." She was surprised and interested because she had read the book. This always happened; people were more interested when they knew about my dad's book.

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship called Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice was wrong. There was a problem with the computer system, and everyone had to wait. People were getting upset because they paid a lot for the trip and wanted it to be nice.
Violet wanted to leave, but she realized she lost her phone. This was more annoying than the long wait. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left her phone in the taxi because all her phone numbers were saved on her phone. Her son Harry always told her to be careful about this. She asked a friendly couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to look for her phone at home.
Finally, the line started moving, and Violet gave her travel papers to get on the ship. She felt disappointed when she saw the ship's entrance. It looked like a hotel that tried to be fancy but wasn't. There were shiny fake wood panels, lots of chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. She took the elevator, which was crowded with tired people, to her room on the twelfth floor. She was happy to see her room had a balcony, just like she wanted. She had paid extra to make sure she could see the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was finding the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 pictures by Maier, a street photographer who took interesting photos. Now, Maloof has a big collection of Maier’s work. In his home, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, plus many movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and felt lucky. ‘When I bought this, I didn’t know what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I could have sold it all to someone else.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent her childhood in France. In 1951, she went back to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was private and always had a camera. She wore big coats, hats, and strong shoes. ‘On her day off, she had her camera and we didn’t see her until night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. She was not very social but liked to walk with her camera and talk to people, sometimes recording them. She loved taking pictures of the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anything stop her.’ Maier’s work was pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often showed women, children, old people, and the poor. ‘Vivian’s pictures are very interesting,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees other photographers’ influence in her work and wonders if she made her own style. ‘Was Vivian very skilled or did she copy others?’ Maloof wonders if he will ever see all the negatives, which he keeps in three big, safe cabinets. He wasn’t interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. ‘As I learned more about photography, I saw that Maier cared about people and street scenes,’ he said. ‘There was more to her work than I thought. Now, we want people to know her name and put Vivian Maier in history books.’

Eleanor Catton wrote a book called The Luminaries. It is a very successful book, and she became famous when she was still in her twenties. I talked to her in the UK when she was very busy with interviews. She was calm, even though she had just traveled from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a funny story about being stopped at passport control. They asked her to prove she was a writer, so she showed them her book. The officer asked, "What’s it about?" This is a hard question for a writer. 
The Luminaries is set in New Zealand in the 1860s. There are many crimes, and 12 men try to solve them. The story is very complex. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a history book, but she found the past made the story more interesting. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good part in the story.
When I asked her about being successful at a young age, she said it was nice because people in her small country, New Zealand, feel proud of her success. She said, "I got a lot of back pats from other people’s grandmas." She also said it is annoying when people think her book is not serious. 
Catton had an idea to write the book like a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. The book gets faster as you read. She said it doesn’t matter if readers notice this, but if they do, they can see the patterns. Even with this special structure, The Luminaries is still an exciting murder mystery. She didn’t plan the whole story before writing. She liked to write herself into difficult situations and then find creative ways out. She wanted the book to be fun for readers.
We also talked about her love for TV drama series. The Luminaries has cliff-hangers and different viewpoints, like a TV show. I asked if she would like to write for TV. She said, "That could be pretty cool." She was very excited when talking about writing and New Zealand. She said being in different places changes her imagination. Some writers leave New Zealand to be around more people, but for now, she will stay there. I hope New Zealand gives her ideas for more books.

When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. These hobbies became his job for the last 40 years: he makes steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. Jonny says, ‘I love the guitar. It’s amazing how two pieces of wood can make a beautiful sound. Using different wood makes different sounds. It still surprises me.’
Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted a bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you want something, you make it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and wood types change the sound.’
The bass was the first instrument Jonny made, but he and his brothers had already made other things like model boats and planes. ‘We drew them and then built them. My father taught us how to use tools. I also fixed instruments for my friends.’
Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. He liked painting and sculpture too. After school, he studied architecture at university because he liked design. But he left halfway through. ‘I was too different for it,’ he says. ‘But I learned that guitar-making is like sculpture. You make something people use, and it’s more practical than art.’
Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of materials. But as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just getting by.’ He can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings.
In the early years, Jonny worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals and asked musicians to try his guitars and talk about him. He also learned how to price his guitars, which was hard for him.
Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought only American guitars were good,’ he says. ‘But now UK-made guitars are respected.’ Jonny says learning in a classroom is good, and new makers should take courses. But he also believes in learning by trying things. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you learn from someone else, you learn one way. If you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’

When English people talk, they often start with the weather. This is a tradition. A famous writer, Dr. Johnson, said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This was true 200 years ago and is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting. But this is not true. The weather in England is not very exciting. There are no big storms or tornadoes. Some people, like the writer Bill Bryson, say the English weather is boring. Others, like broadcaster Jeremy Paxman, say it is interesting because it is always changing. But both are missing the point. English people talk about the weather to start conversations. It is a way to say hello or to fill a silence. When someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" they are not really asking about the weather. They are just starting a conversation. This is like how monkeys groom each other to be friendly. English people use weather talk in three ways: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or to fill a silence. This is why it seems like they talk about the weather a lot. But really, it is just a way to be polite and talk to each other.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to tell her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip instead of going to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She couldn't find a good historical novel about life at the Wall, so she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started writing books in 2001. She said teaching was like acting and very tiring, but writing was exciting and less exhausting. Her old teaching friends were jealous because she still connected with children through her books. Alice wants her books to be different from other children's books, which are often about dark or fantasy stories. She likes to teach English and History together and loves when children go from being bored to interested. Writing is like teaching for her. She started writing her first novel when her sons were leaving home and her head teacher suggested a creative writing course. At first, she didn't want to do it, but she had to send a story to join the course. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and told her to publish it. Alice asked for a year off from teaching to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, helped her edit the book. He is a critic and editor, and his help was important. Alice says they work well together because he helps improve her writing.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 
‘I’m excited,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done this before. The roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll stay warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. He wore winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair joked, ‘I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for tea halfway.’
The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Fleet Moss, the highest road in Yorkshire, 350 meters up. The car might have an easy time, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside, while Jonny drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. Who would get there first?
Jonny’s confidence dropped quickly. Just 15 seconds into the drive, a big tractor blocked the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair wins, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving. Alistair struggled with the hill and had to carry his bike over fences. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top and started going faster.
Jonny faced more problems. The roads were narrow and not made for speed. He had to drive slowly through a village and a stream on the road. Once past the village, he raced to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. Jonny sped to Fleet Moss, while Alistair rode across a field and onto the road from the other side. Alistair reached the finish line first. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He celebrated with his arms up. Minutes later, Jonny arrived. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said sadly. ‘I’m disappointed.’

'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, the first thing you notice is the silence. You bounce the ball on the soft grass; you serve it and hear the sound of your own shot. The grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel like you are in a different world. The silence helps me focus on my game. I try to think only about the match and the point I am playing. When a point is over, the silence breaks with applause and cheers. I hear them, but they feel far away. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me or the millions around the world. I am focused on playing Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me it was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I would play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice. In 2006, I was just happy to be there, but in 2007, losing was very hard. I knew I could have played better. I cried a lot after that loss. My uncle Toni, who is usually very tough, told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it might have been my last chance. I know a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I had another chance in 2008. I was sure I learned from my loss the year before. I believed I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we didn’t talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She wrote to her family, saying, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa. She became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made Jane famous with articles and TV shows about her work with chimpanzees. She also wrote books for children and adults, including the popular book "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. Some people think her fame hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams but do not show her true work. Jane Goodall helped us understand chimpanzees better. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees eat meat or use tools. We also did not know that they have emotions and social systems like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Jane studied wild apes in Gombe, Nigeria, and her work is considered a great scientific achievement. She changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five years old, she disappeared one day. The police and her family searched for her. She came back with straw in her hair and clothes. She had been hiding in a henhouse to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity was the start of her career as a biologist.'

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist. She can speak like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are known from children's TV shows, cartoons, and health and safety videos. Shirley says that doing voiceovers is more than just funny voices. You have to make the script come alive for people who can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceovers, but they often don't get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.
Shirley studied drama and wanted to be a regular actor. She sang jingles for TV ads and once tried out for a rabbit in a cartoon. She got the part and realized she could do voices. In her second film, she played the main character and her brother and mother. Female actors often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. Shirley learns new voices by watching children's TV.
Shirley does many types of voiceover work, from cartoons to vacuum cleaner ads. She says it's important to sound happy, even if you don't care about the product. Smiling while talking helps make your voice sound cheerful. Animation work is fun because she interacts with other actors.
The competition for voiceover work is tough. A good showreel, which is a recording of what you can do, is important. Shirley says you need to be determined and not give up. She suggests going to workshops to learn about voiceovers. Shirley loves voices and sometimes keeps speaking in a character's voice even after work. Her children are used to her talking in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because being a cartoonist is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more realistic ones, like being a lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make money by drawing doodles like the ones in school notebooks. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 
For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college. After college, I showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that needed political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on.
To be a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even to be great at drawing. You need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But it’s not easy. It’s a hard job, and you should only do it if you can’t imagine doing anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family and hobbies.
The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about everything.
What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists had regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but not good at business.
Some people worry that others will steal their ideas, even if they have never sold a cartoon. They don’t let others see their work. To protect your work, you just need to draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar made in Japan. I usually don't like to throw things away, so why did I want to get rid of it? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, but I already felt a little sad. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. After that, I often felt sad about what I did.
A few months ago, I got an email that surprised me. It was from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes and sells guitars. He said, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address sticker on the back of the guitar. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell the guitar back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. Keith's price was fair, and I was glad to pay it. I had forgotten that my dad liked to put name-and-address stickers on everything, even my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this story!
My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular then. I liked the sound of the classical guitar because it was calming and gentle. But I didn't get very good at it, so I switched to the electric guitar. At that time, punk music was popular, and you didn't have to play very well to be a rock star. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. The guitar felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I picked it up and felt like I needed to stand up to play it. My fingers remembered how to play the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingers hurt a little from pressing the strings, but it felt good.
The electric guitar is not usually played alone, so I think I need to start a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call our band "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote a book about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one talking about how bad it is not to get enough sleep. Not sleeping enough affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them. We often lose dreams when we wake up early. The last part of sleep, called REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement', is when we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen in REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years dreaming. When people don't get enough REM sleep, they have more intense dreams the next night. This shows that dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM sleep, and many agreed with Sigmund Freud, a famous psychologist, who said that understanding dreams helps us understand our minds. But it wasn't that simple. Later studies showed that dreams come from physical, not just psychological, origins. Now, there is not much agreement among dream researchers. Dreams are important. At a meeting, a study showed that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams more than other people. This is because they are interested in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with dreams because films are like dreams. But I wonder, do only artistic people need dreams? Everyone, like teachers and software designers, needs to think creatively. Dreams help us connect ideas in new ways. For example, when people wake up from REM sleep and are asked to think of a word, their answers are more original. This is what creativity is. I write better after intense dreams. Even a dream I can barely remember helps me think better. Creativity is not just for artists. We all need to think creatively in our complex world. We need to dream to help us with our relationships and work.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, you can see the sea and photos of her two daughters, but no paintings. Susie is a famous copyist artist. She can paint like famous artists from the past, such as Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her paintings look so real that even art experts can be fooled. The original paintings are worth millions, but Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. 
Susie has many clients, including galleries and private collectors. Some collectors pretend her copies are the real thing. One famous person likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. Some people use her copies to save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank. Susie always signs her name on the back of her paintings. She knows it is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and she does not want to get into trouble. 
Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She did not earn much money, but it helped her learn to draw accurately. Now, she advises young artists to learn to draw well and study hard. Susie can copy many styles, but she likes French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas the most. 
Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it is not. The impressionists painted quickly but carefully, and it is hard to do both. Susie does not paint her own original art because she enjoys copying and makes a good living from it. She once tried painting fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist and likes to do things perfectly.

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea and wanted to be the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was very interested in sailing. When she was on her boat, she felt like it was part of her. On land, she felt life was not as exciting, and she wanted to go back to the sea. After she finished second in a big solo race around the world, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She lived there for 94 days. She planned everything carefully, like how much kitchen paper she needed. She showed me her food, stove, and medical supplies. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.
Later, Ellen went to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. She helped with a bird survey and saw old whaling stations. This made her think about how we use the Earth's resources. She realized we need to change how we use things like coal, oil, and gas because they are running out. She started talking about re-using things and visited factories and power stations to learn more. She wants to help save the planet.
Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation to teach young people about a sustainable future. She misses the adventure of sailing but feels her new work is more important. She wants to use her voice to make a difference. She says this work is more meaningful than being the fastest sailor.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan wants to inspire them to go outside and try new things. Jordan's team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty years old. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.
Some experienced climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young climber might be strong enough, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing. The Romeros know about these opinions. Paul says, ‘I know people criticize us, but I can’t focus on that – we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.’
I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father wants him to? Paul says, ‘This is not about me wanting to be famous because of my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it.’ When I ask Jordan why he likes the challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on reaching my goal.’
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This is a problem for Jordan. People might say that trying to set records is more important than enjoying the climb, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story. This means writing online, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, ‘If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.’

'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I am studying music at university, but my classmates don't know much about classical music either. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't have their music. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and classical CDs sell only about 300 copies each. This is surprising for someone who loves classical music. Why is classical music less popular now? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. Classical music doesn't interest most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. Some teenagers do like classical music, but they are few. I play in an orchestra, but I am not a big fan of classical music. I like many types of music, but I listen to classical music only a little. Why don't teenagers like classical music? Classical music changes mood a lot, and teenagers like things fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, and its topics are more interesting to teenagers. In the past, families played music together at home, and concerts were the only other way to hear music. Now, we can find any music online, but we don't often choose classical. You don't hear classical music in shops. One of my teachers says more people go to classical concerts now, but not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play in many places, but the audience is mostly older people. Teenagers often avoid things their parents like. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids enjoy playing it in school orchestras. They practice a lot, but when they relax, they choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said quietly. Her mother was getting out of the other side of the car and didn’t hear her. Bonnie didn’t mind if her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school with many buildings hidden among trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre. "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be in trouble soon anyway," she thought, "so why not start now?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She was careful and respectful as she went to the horses. Bonnie liked horses. The horses were well cared for, she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony as she touched its nose. The next horse surprised her. "You’re the best one here!" she said. He was brown with a little white. He looked lively, and Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, petting his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you in a big competition." His name was Maverick. She wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle," she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Bonnie was happy. She put a saddle on Maverick and forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen.
