Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed when she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said. "I know about horses, even if I don’t know about other things." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the wind made her cheeks glow. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I met Cody Simpson before, and I liked how he was quietly confident. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia who has made many popular songs. How did a relaxed surfer become a famous singer? Cody says, "I started playing guitar when I was six and writing songs at seven." He remembers that he was swimming and surfing every day. These activities were very important to him. When he was 13, he was in high school and posted some videos online. These videos changed his life. He first posted a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. People liked it and wanted more videos. Cody made more videos at home and shared them. Many people loved them.
Cody was also a very good swimmer. He trained with top coaches and worked hard at swimming. But then music companies noticed him. He had to choose: stay in Australia and swim or move to the US for music. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was hard for me to choose a career at such a young age," he says. He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise for many people. I'm a quiet person," he says. Cody and his family moved to the US, leaving one dream to follow another. His family stays out of the spotlight but supports him. Cody thinks it's important to have good people around you to stay grounded.
Sometimes Cody worries about his family, especially his little brother and sister. His brother is eight and travels a lot, doing school on the road. Cody wonders how this affects him. But his family always supports and encourages him. Success comes from saying "yes" to big opportunities, even if they are scary. "Everything happened so fast," Cody says. "Now, I visit countries I never thought I would and play for many fans. It's a dream for many people, but I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed and looked out the window at the river. There was a new crack in the ice shining in the sunlight. I looked at the sandbags we put up last week to stop the river from flooding. My back still hurt from lifting them. I worked with many people from the town to do this. My grandfather didn’t notice much. I looked at the river where the water was dark and open because of the factory. I saw a boy I didn’t know trying to walk on the ice. I put on my kayaking wetsuit and jacket. I checked my pocket for a silver chain my grandfather gave me. It’s special to me. I also have his diary from a trip to South America. I read it before I sleep. I went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I almost bumped into Grandpa in the hallway. ‘Watch where you’re going,’ he said. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ He knows I kayak every morning. Grandpa gets angry sometimes, but I try to ignore it. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. That hurt, but I took a deep breath. He went into the bathroom. Mom said, ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself,’ I said. I used to think he was a hero when I was a child. He has photos in National Geographic and medals in his room. I don’t go there anymore. I have my own trophies now. But I still care about him. Mom said, ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination!’ I smiled and said, ‘It’ll be warmer in South America if I get sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed. I ate my banana and went to the boathouse.

Mum took Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, against the wall, was a painting. It was Grandpa's work, but different from his other paintings and not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. There was a big river, but she didn't know it. Maybe it wasn't a real river, just a fantasy one. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was small, just a little green, and the eye was drawn to the pale waters and a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this picture. But Jess was interested, thinking of autumn after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, like she was hiding her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others understand them if they could. Mum turned the picture over and showed the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? Maybe he will add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would say. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without explaining it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting, since you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" "Someone who gives an artist ideas." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint. He would say the muse wasn't kind to him today or he needed to be nice to the muse for a difficult part. He never said the muse was her. She thought it was a goddess, not a person. It was hard to think anyone, even a goddess, could influence Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

'When I woke up this morning, I did not plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I am not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet by itself. I am not saying that happened, just that it could have. I did not mean to damage the carpet. I did not wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. I am unlucky that way. I was not thinking about cutting holes. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is very cute! It is small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept china ornaments in it. I keep my shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her cabinet. I was so happy when she gave it to me! But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom. My room is the smallest in the house, under the roof, and shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But Angela is only fifteen, so I will be in my small room for a long time. I do not mind; I like my little bedroom. It is cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a little too tall. If I could cut a few centimetres off the bottom... Then I had an idea. If I could not cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. And that is what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of very small people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to make a TV show of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the show to be from the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more difficult. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was making the shadows look right when the tiny Borrowers were shown with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special way to do this. After the show was on TV, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was very strange and fun. When I asked them to carry big things like a giant pair of scissors, they really enjoyed it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh a lot. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right. I made them from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the main actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit down during breaks, and she couldn’t take the dress off because it was sewn on every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for the detailed costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. We didn’t have money for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work fast – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series showed the magic of the books well.

Mom stops the car at my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously for journalists, but there are none. I know the attention will come soon. People will want to be my friend or ask for free tickets to my dad's concerts. I tell Mom, "Everything’s going to be fine." She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. She drives away, leaving me to face this new school and new situation. I wanted this change to get away from my old life on the road. While the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I chose this school to meet real kids. Maybe kids with parents who work regular jobs. That would be so normal and cool.
I walk into the school office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw," I reply. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types my last name. Not many people know my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" she asks. "Eleventh," I answer. "One second, it’s printing," she says and gives me my schedule. English Literature is my first class. I like English, so that's good. I will be late, though. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night to find my classes easily.
When I reach the classroom, the teacher is already calling names. I quietly sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with flowers. I knew they might give me away. "Thanks," I say. The teacher calls my name, "Desert McGraw?" "Here," I reply. The teacher, Ms. Smigla, smiles and gives us our course outlines. After talking about the books we need to read, she lets us socialize. 
"Why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have choices. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras? Or the real reason my dad gave? "We need a change, Desert," he said. "This is the perfect place to record the new album." I think he just wants to relax on the beach. "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. "What does he do?" she asks. Everyone will find out soon, but I want to be normal for now. "He’s an artist," I say. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way," she says, not really interested. Perfect.

'Today, American teenage girls are expected to do many things. They should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in everything. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Teenage boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough. People think that if you do not try very hard, you are lazy. Teenagers have a lot of pressure. They have homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores at home, and they also try to have a social life. Kristen Loose, a teenager, says this is normal for teenagers today. But people still think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and only care about themselves. Kristen says this is not true. Many people think teenagers spend all their time watching TV or on their phones. Kristen says she uses her phone to help her with her life, not just for fun. Teenagers need to be connected all the time. They use smartphones and tablets to do their homework anywhere. Schoolwork and activities do not stop when school ends. Teenagers often start their day at 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They do not get enough sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation says only 20% of teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Many teenagers fall asleep in school because they are tired. Lindamarie Olsen, another teenager, says she has about 18 hours of free time a week. She does not waste this time on social media or TV. She likes to volunteer and help others. She wants to make a positive impact in her school and community. In the future, teenagers will continue to change the world and prove stereotypes wrong.'

The Earth to Sky Calculus Club is a group of teenagers from Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. They have launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers like it. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to try and record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and makes a light trail. 
As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a tool to measure how high the balloon goes, and a thermometer to check temperature changes. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find the lunch box later. They used a gas tank to fill the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had traveled seven hours to get the gas tank. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For these kids, this is normal. 
Finally, it was time to launch the balloon. They counted down, ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ and the balloon started to rise. Some teenagers ran and followed it with flashlights until it was out of sight. There was a quiet feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky. It was hard to believe they were just four hours from Los Angeles, a big city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor crossed the sky.
As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. The lunch box usually lands in a remote area because there is not much inhabited land around Bishop. ‘Recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader. They have lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘We have learned a lot about this landscape,’ he added.
This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, especially if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘These students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild to some is normal for them.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was on a flat rock in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars, which was a bit disappointing. But it was a chance to talk about atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. It was also another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan says she didn't like science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. It happened by chance. Her younger brother loved dinosaurs, which is common for kids, but Chloe didn't care much. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new dinosaur discoveries. It amazed her, and she decided she wanted to study Palaeontology.
Chloe met her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. She was nervous because she thought he might find her annoying with her questions. But he was patient and listened to her, which made her feel comfortable.
Chloe talks about how movies and TV shows show palaeontologists. She says films like Jurassic Park make people interested in dinosaurs but not always in Palaeontology. She thinks movies often show palaeontologists as strange geniuses or awkward people, which is not true. Her job is very different. She digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs, and writes for science magazines. She also likes to explain science to the public, especially young people, to help them understand more about science.
Chloe helped with a TV documentary called Walking with Dinosaurs. She says the people making the show knew a lot, and she only gave advice if needed. The dinosaurs in the show were very realistic and different from those in movies like Jurassic Park.
Chloe thinks dinosaurs fascinate us because they make us feel like explorers. They remind us there is still more to discover in the world. Palaeontology is like traveling back in time.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know you are not "there" yet, even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" Once you arrive, it becomes "here," not "there." So, you should ask, "Are we here yet?" Parents probably want to be "there" more than kids do because they hear this question a lot during long trips.
Kids often complain, but think about it: you can relax in the back seat, watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, your mum or dad gives you juice boxes, cookies, and changes the radio or temperature to keep you happy.
But sometimes, things go wrong. Like when my younger brother, Tim, puts his foot on my side of the seat. I do the same, and soon we are fighting. Mum or dad has to stop us and tell Tim to stay in his seat. Then, everything is calm again, and we enjoy the view.
Later, I feel a breeze on my arm. It's Tim, blowing air on me from his seat. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. I get angry, and Tim gets in trouble again. Then, things calm down once more.
Dad has ways to handle us in the car. When we ask, "Are we there yet?" he sometimes says, "Yes, get out of the car." But we are still on the highway, so we know we are not there yet. This makes us quiet for a while.
You know you are finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids. So remember, if mum and dad can still answer your question, then no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK. In their café, people can drink coffee, eat cake, and play board games. John and Zuzi hope people will enjoy this and come back again. Zuzi says they started the café because people spend too much time on phones and gadgets. They want people to talk and have fun together without screens.
The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have simple themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, made by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources. Everyone stays involved, and no one feels left out. Later, 'co-operative' games were made, where players work together as a team. One example is Pandemic, made by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players solve global problems together.
Matt Leacock loved board games since he was a child. He was often disappointed with games, so he started making better ones with his uncle. Pandemic became very popular. It tells a story, like a video game, where players develop characters and face new challenges.
Video games have helped board games become popular. Many people now play games on their phones. Ben Hogg, who works for a games company, says more people are open to playing games now. Before, people played video games together in the same room. Now, many video games are played online, and players are not together physically. So, some people want to play games with others in person again.
John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun. In our online world, people like to share games in real life, and this trend will continue.

Jamie Scott is a famous music writer and producer from the UK. His story shows why it is important to keep trying in the music business, even if things don't go well at first. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. At home, he only listened to a radio station for older people, which influenced his music taste. He first heard a modern song when he was 12 years old. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he was very good at, and music. He spent his school lunchtimes playing the piano. Jamie decided he didn't want to play tennis forever because it was too hard. At 17, he left school to become a musician. He was in a music duo with a friend, but his friend didn't want to make music a career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to be a musician and had been writing songs during school. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he got a music deal at 19 because of one song. But the labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he left his friend. Jamie became successful behind the scenes, writing songs for others. He changed record labels to release a new album, but it didn't make him famous. Jamie says he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but as a writer, he was in the right place. He is now a top writer in the UK, helping new artists start their careers. Jamie believes writing songs that can be popular is important. He wants to write big hits that many people will listen to. Jamie is honest about wanting to write number one songs and knows he is good at it. He focuses on writing the best music and creating classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of famous person. He is very popular online, but many people who do not watch online videos might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist.' This means he does tricks on a bike, like jumping from a roof to a wall. These tricks are filmed and shared online.
I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. Many local boys knew him, and even older people came to say he is a 'legend.' After watching his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each trick, Tony explained what he wanted to do, and I was not always sure he could do it. But he did, and when I praised him, he seemed not very interested. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans and prefers doing tricks instead of talking about them.
Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. This technology helps him make a living from his videos. He says, 'This technology gives people like me a chance to earn money.' But he also feels that people spend too much time with cameras and screens. Still, he is happy because he can make money from what used to be just a hobby.
I have learned that to become a top athlete, you need energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even Tony sometimes falls when trying new tricks, but he gets up and tries again until he succeeds.
Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some people say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people do not understand his sport. They do not know he gets advice from experts to stay safe. Tony is careful about risks. He says, 'Some people never get scared, but they should be careful. I feel fear but find a way to overcome it. I am not addicted to risk. I plan and prepare a lot. Sometimes I ride around to get ready before a new trick. I know I must be confident before I jump. If I am fully committed, I am okay.'

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous things for charity. She ran a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she knew some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. ‘The training was a surprise,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know I needed to be so strong. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill. Then, I did an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also learned how to fall on the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she walked step by step on the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said after. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But Helen is still planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing. A penny farthing is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Before this, Jeff wrote a book about traveling in Canada in a very old car. He loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even went to Amsterdam on it for a holiday. ‘That trip made me want to see the world by bike,’ he says. Jeff didn’t want a normal bike, and he wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bike I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to learn how to make one.’ He tried to start his trip in 2001 and 2003, but he had to stop because of a knee injury. Finally, in 2006, he started his journey. He traveled for three years and visited 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was seeing Mount Everest in Tibet. ‘I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I couldn’t do, but I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I traveled, the more people were amazed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and stayed in a hostel bed for ten days without medicine. He had no money for hospital bills or to go home. But Jeff says, ‘if I had the money, I would travel again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US. My team and I study water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks at night. We are worried about black ducks because there are fewer of them now. We don't know if they have enough food on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night. Before, we didn't have the right tools to see them at night. But now, with the new scope, we can see them clearly, even when there is no moon. This will help us learn more and take better care of the places where they live. 
The work is hard. There are four people on our team, and each of us works six hours every day. We study ducks in different places. I have to take a boat to some places and write down notes about every duck I see. The weather is not always good. Some nights are nice, but many nights are rainy. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. 
I like the challenge of this work. In the summer, we will spend many hours in a laboratory looking at our results. It will be hard to stay inside, but it is important to do this. I wouldn't change my job for anything!

'When I tell people about my job, they can't believe it. But it's true! I work by eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get the best chocolate from my company. Every week, I get small pieces of chocolate from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the nuts, fruit, and other things we use in the chocolate. I spend time choosing the best ones. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste the chocolate I make. I give samples to my coworkers, and they like it! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients. It's nice to have a private space to work. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I am in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy ingredients. I have a young family, so traveling can be hard. But I like the variety and not having a routine. I love the chocolate most of all! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I still love eating it. I even eat more chocolate at home in the evening!'

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which is flying through the air above an audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can watch some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia says that for a circus career, performers need to do different things to keep shows exciting. To be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great thing is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have imagination, and always try to get better. People often think you might get hurt or only work a little each year. But the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel with the circus when you're young, and then you need to think about other jobs. The course also teaches business planning. Many past students have started businesses around the world and like to share their stories. Sophia warns that it's not a job for making a lot of money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive - but a lot of fun!"

'You might not know her name or her face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She helps the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers. That is not true – they have to be very good. People like Mariam are important in the music world! ‘What I love about my job is that when I go to the recording studio, I never know what I will sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask. One time, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘Excellent musical skills are important for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to look at. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very hard because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already.’ ‘One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can find out how to make it better.’

Julie Deane started with only a little fashion knowledge. She made a successful business with her 'satchels', which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous shops and many celebrities use them. Before choosing satchels, Julie thought about different businesses like cake decorating and party planning. She did not choose her first idea. When she decided on satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She worked with her family from the start, especially her mother, who is good at business. The design of the bags came from children's storybooks. Julie did not know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her a lot. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and more people became interested. Now, her company makes satchels faster. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is using a satchel. Other companies spend money on online ads, but Julie uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles. This keeps her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design. Now, she makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. People say her office has a positive feeling, and everyone loves working there. There is a new factory now, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork.
When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling. He bought a special bike for racing and started joining competitions. Vicky thought it looked fun and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily go to training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. But when she was 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning, but I got tired of it. When it’s not exciting anymore, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new job.’
Vicky started working for a charity called CycleZone. ‘We help young people who don’t like sports,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves. CycleZone does a great job and brings young people together.’
The charity uses famous people to talk about their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people think celebrities only help to make themselves look good, and this can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson is a singer and songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to become more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert. 
A year later, Ana's brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She liked it so much that she joined a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Ana was the youngest student, but she knew a lot about music. However, the teacher did not listen to her ideas, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about how this made her feel. She put the song online, and it became very popular. People left comments saying they loved it and found new meanings in the words each time they listened.
Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, came from the other side of Ireland to ask Ana to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know the company and did not want anyone to tell her what to sing. But Joss convinced her this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. All the tickets sold quickly, and it was a great evening.
Ana says she likes to write songs about difficult times because there is more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him unhappy. Ana hopes her fans will like her songs, but her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat with a group along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t. I wanted to visit the area because I saw it on TV when I was a child. Our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I asked Harry if I could go too, and he finally said yes! A few days before we left, there were storms where we were going. But the weather was going to be calm when we were there. I was busy at work, so I didn’t have much time to plan. But Harry said he took care of everything, so I stopped worrying. When we got to Canada, we joined the group, put our things in small boats, and started the trip. The guide said not many people lived along the coast. On the first morning, we only saw dolphins and birds. There were islands far away, but it was foggy, so we couldn’t see them well. I watched the nice patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped to explore rock pools on the beaches. They had many colorful fish that I didn’t know. It was nice not to worry about time. We always made lunch and dinner together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. The beds were hard, but it was a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I also wanted to tell everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think I would love basketball because of this, but I didn't. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games. 
When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed to get better before playing a real game. The teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I played my first game against another school. My mum and dad came to watch, which made me nervous, but it went well in the end!
For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't like being far from my parents at first. At home, I didn't have much time with friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. I got used to my new life, and my English got better quickly!
I became a professional basketball player at eighteen, three years after moving to the USA. I was taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to work on that. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college. I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I decided to become a weekend tour guide in my city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and found out that I really liked it. I saw my city in a new way, like the tourists did. After I finished my studies, I wanted to be a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that I needed to know a lot more. In Chicago, guides must answer many questions about the city, like its buildings, history, and transport. After some hard but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and became an independent tour guide. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts or keeping the group together. You need to be fun and tell good stories. You also need to handle changes, like if a place is closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy the tour, not hear about problems. I make sure my visitors are happy, so they don’t write bad reviews online. Good reviews bring more customers. I work hard to make my tours fun and easy, and my reviews are usually very good. Many people recommend my tours to other visitors in Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Josie is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to help as volunteers at an elephant sanctuary. This is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. But in the end, we did not need to worry.
One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even if I got wetter than the elephants!
The part of the day I liked most was the evening. We walked with the elephants into the forest where they stayed at night. All the volunteers lived in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so it was small. We chose this because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we knew it would be like that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff talked and played games.
Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she liked the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I am not sure she is being honest. I think she is a bit upset because she missed her friends too much and did not enjoy her time there fully. But when she thinks about it, she knows she was lucky to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I know I will!

My name is Gina D’Costa, and I have a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many people, not just for friends or homes. Hotels and offices like to have flowers in their Reception areas. Sometimes, we help with photo sessions for businesses by giving them flowers for their pictures. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very happy with what we did.
My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still sleeping then, and my friends think I am crazy, but I love my job. It is often cold and dark, but I don’t mind. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. There are so many colors and smells, it is hard to choose. If I chose for myself, I would pick only pink flowers because it is my favorite color. But I have to remember that other people might like different flowers. Not all flowers are available all year, so sometimes I cannot find what customers want.
I don’t like arguing about prices with the flower-sellers, but it is part of the job. Flowers are not cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and put flowers in vases. Then we make flower bunches and decide how much they will cost. Customers are often surprised by the price, and I sometimes ask them to choose again. Some people think this is too much work, but I enjoy making the best flower bunches for the money people want to spend. I love my job and wouldn’t want to do anything else!

'My city has a modern cinema that shows all the new films I want to see. It also shows many films for kids on the weekends. The cinema is close to my home. But a year ago, I felt something was missing. I wanted to talk about films with people after watching them. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema to show films. Instead, we choose a new place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the film feel real and exciting! Some places are free because the owners sell snacks during the film. This helps us keep our prices low. We just want to cover our costs, not make money. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own equipment. We also sell tickets online, so we know how many people are coming. There is always a lot to do, but when people say they had a great time, it feels wonderful. Our website helps us connect with other film clubs in the country. We visit them to see how they do things, but we love coming back to our club. We also started a blog because people look online for film information now. We tried putting posters in cafés, but people telling their friends about us works best. The audience loves the special activities we do with each film. Last month, we had a movie quiz, and everyone enjoyed it.'

When I was a child, I loved taking photos. When I was 15, I wanted to make my hobby more serious. So, I started a special project: I would take one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to make a photo diary and show my photos to other people. I was happy to see that some people liked my photos. I enjoyed taking pictures of many different things. Then, someone told me that my project would be better if all my photos had a common topic. I agreed and started taking more photos of nature, like birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different because most young photographers took color photos. Sometimes, I felt unsure about my project and almost stopped. But I trusted myself and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos for fun. I was so happy when the judges said I won first prize. It was the first time I thought my photography was really good, and maybe I could be a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I am happy with my career choice.

Last year, I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) because they do camping, sailing, and teach skills like public speaking. I had never done these things before. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called 'leaders' help you. When you finish each level, you get a certificate.
When I first joined, my leader said I should help organize activities at a local children's club for two hours a week. I wasn't sure it was a good idea because I went to that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. But I decided to try the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate.
Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children's club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I made good relationships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to it.
Because of what I learned at the children's club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a youth worker, someone who works with children. I never thought about this before starting at the club. I had never thought about my future job, and the idea of youth work was new to me. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and had not thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to love it too. In the end, I did well. After that, I started to love snowboarding and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people get bored of snowboarding, but I still love it and like winning. This helps me try harder. I like not having a fixed plan. Once, I got a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I was not sure I would try the jumps, but I did, and it made me trust myself more. In the summer, I train and study because there is no snow. I train every day, but I do not have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend time with my friends. It helps me when I cannot snowboard. I think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I want to have another option in case I do not become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I am thinking about becoming a doctor if I can find time for college. I cannot imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I cannot do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had. I didn't think about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday. I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it if I paid for it myself. So, I decided to work part-time and save money. This taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't like it. My parents suggested I start my own small business. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try. I thought it was hard, but it was easier than I expected. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked the idea. Mum showed me how to make nice things at home with simple tools. I sold my first jewellery to friends and family. They said they liked them, but I thought they were just being nice. I wanted to know if other people would like them too. So, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists come to my town, and they bought my jewellery as gifts. Soon, people from all over the country called to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just me and my mum at the market stall! That's when I knew it could work, and I decided to make a website. Since then, I have made a lot of money from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun.

When Janine Stuart was only 13 years old, she wrote a book called Being Amelia. This book became very popular. Being Amelia is a little bit about Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine said, "Because of my dad’s job, my family moved a lot, so I got good at making new friends. I know how it feels to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, starting at a new school. Some funny parts of the book are about Amelia’s life at home, especially with her older brother. I don’t have brothers or sisters, so I used my imagination for that." Janine started writing her book one summer when she was bored at home. Her mom always wanted to be a writer, and her teachers always told her to write, so it was a good way for Janine to spend her time. The year before, she won a short story competition on a website for young writers. Because of this, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were excited to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s book was in stores. One review of Being Amelia says that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the story is about people facing hard problems, which makes readers believe in them. The reviewer says that even though Janine is young and her book is not very long, she is a better writer than some other popular authors. Janine is still getting used to being famous: "At first, I hid when people saw me on the street, but now it’s OK. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just spend time with my friends, and then I have something interesting to write about!"

Hi, I'm Tom. I'm fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. My father got a job as the castle's manager. He works for a group that takes care of old buildings and lets people visit them. He was happy because he thought he might not get another chance like this. At first, we were not sure if Dad should take the job. We were thinking about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as nice as our home across the water, and there was no school on the island. But after we moved, we got used to living there. The castle is not very pretty, but our apartment is nice. In summer, the island is busy with visitors, and there are parties on the beach. In winter, we only see the other families on the island, and there are not many teenagers. The adults help each other with fixing things, which is hard work. The biggest change for me was taking a boat to my old school every day. I was excited to go on stormy days with big waves, but the boats don't go then! If I miss the bus to the harbour after school, I miss the last boat home, which is a problem. So when friends come to stay with me, I tell them to hurry up! But we see amazing views, like the sunset over the sea. Some days, it's so foggy you can't see anything, then it's sunny again in a few hours. It's still surprising when that happens. We do have bad storms, and I sometimes worry if the castle is strong enough. But then I remember it's been here for hundreds of years, and it's still standing!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I love nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family. We saw many birds in their natural home. I spent hours watching them with my parents. They taught me how to tell different birds apart and where to find them. It was amazing! After we came home, I joined a local young birdwatchers’ club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species. I am close to reaching this goal because on family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America. I thought I would see my 200th bird species there. I didn’t see it, but I learned that you have to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about my challenge. Many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I wasn’t nervous until just before I started speaking. I knew what to say and had notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I relaxed when it was over. The teachers said I did well and they enjoyed it. I might do another one next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and soon I became a good player. My family thought I would stop playing football like I did with other hobbies, but I didn’t. I dreamed of playing football professionally when I grew up. 
One day, I played in a local tournament, and a referee saw that I was a good player. He told the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. The manager liked how I played and asked me to join her club. I was surprised because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. I started training with the club when I was 13 years old. I got much better at playing football. 
Some people didn’t think I would become a star player, and that made me a little sad. But my coach told me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in a big match earlier than I thought I would. I ran very hard because I didn’t want the team to lose because of me. Luckily, I scored the winning goal. I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals.
Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. We want to get teenagers interested in football and let them talk to other players in my club. They will see what it’s like to play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them is the same as my coach’s advice to me: you will have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I have been lucky to have very few bad times!

In the UK and other countries, schools and universities are now encouraging students to start doing research early in their studies. Research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It is a way to learn and build skills. Research skills are useful in school and at work because they help us think about the world and do our jobs better. As a student, you help create new knowledge by asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? These questions are part of what we call research.
Research can be very complex and done by experts, but it can also be simple and part of everyday life. For example, when you plan a holiday, grow plants, fix things at home, or shop online, you are doing research. In college, you are expected to ask questions, explore information, and create your own ideas. Some students find this hard because, in some places, knowledge is seen as something you get from teachers and books without questioning it. But in the UK, US, and many other places, it is important to question what we know and who tells us what to know.
Critical thinking is very important in research. We should not just repeat what we read or hear. We need to think about it, test it, and see if it makes sense and is supported by evidence. We should not just believe everything we are told without thinking about it carefully.

Cities have always been places where people think and create new ideas. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In Paris, artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art in cafés. But living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera. Picasso moved to the countryside later. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural.
Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains. They found that cities can make our thinking less sharp. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients get better faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature helps our brains because it gives us a break from city life.
More people now live in cities than ever before. We live in crowded places with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a busy city street, our brain has to pay attention to many things: people, traffic, and the city layout. This takes a lot of energy because the brain has to decide what to focus on.
Nature, on the other hand, is easier for our brains. This idea is called attention restoration theory. It says that being in nature helps our brains relax and recharge. Natural places catch our attention without making us feel stressed, unlike loud city noises.
People have known for a long time that cities can be hard on our minds. That's why we have parks like Central Park in New York. Parks give people a break from city life and help our brains work better. Many things, like energy drinks or new office designs, try to help us think better, but a walk in nature is often more effective.
Even though city life can be hard, cities keep growing. They are still places where people come up with new ideas. Research shows that the busy and crowded parts of cities help people be creative. Just like in old London, today's busy cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are centers of new ideas and technology.
The challenge is to find ways to reduce the stress of city life while keeping its benefits. Because sometimes, people still want to say, "I'm tired of nature, take me to the city!"

'Where is the mind? This might seem like a strange question. We usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have special machines that can show this. But I believe the study of the mind should not stop at the head. There is a lot of evidence, from long ago to now, that things outside our heads also help us think. For example, stone tools, jewelry, and writing have helped humans grow and think better. So, I think that what is outside the head can also be part of the mind. 
We often think the mind and the brain are the same because scientists study people without the things around them. This is because brain machines need it that way. But much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not say the brain is not important, but the mind is more than just the brain. Human intelligence also includes culture and the things we use. 
I have a new idea called Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET looks at how things become part of our thinking. For example, when we use clay to make numbers or use a stone to make a tool. It also studies how this has changed over time and what it means for our thinking. This gives us a new way to understand the mind.
Think of a blind person with a stick. Where does this person’s self start? The stick and the person work together. The stick helps the person feel the world, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. This shows that human intelligence can change a lot by using new tools. 
My idea sees the human mind as always changing and growing. The 'stick' can be anything from old stone tools to the internet. It helps us understand and explore the world. Humans use 'sticks' to learn and know more. This is why humans make things, and these things help shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds change as we use different things. 
MET helps us understand how things like stone tools or smartphones change how we think. Technology changes our minds, and humans have used it since the beginning.'

Photography has changed how we see the world. In the United States, it became a big part of culture. Photography is important in many areas like science, industry, art, and entertainment. Some people say it is the US's biggest gift to the visual arts. To understand its impact, we need to look at its start in the mid-19th century.
Why did people like photography so much? First, it was a new technology, and people in the US liked new things. Just like trains and electricity made the world feel smaller, photography brought images of the world into people's homes. Second, people used cameras to show who they were. In the US, people often changed their personal and national identities. Third, cameras helped families keep memories, even if they were a bit idealized. Lastly, photographs looked real and matched the US artists' style of showing everyday life.
A photograph shows what the photographer wants us to see. It is a record of what was in front of the camera. But it also shows the photographer's point of view. People think photography is a 'universal language,' but its meaning can be complex. A photograph's meaning can change depending on where and how we see it, like in a newspaper or a gallery.
To understand a photograph, we need to know why it was taken and how people first saw it. The same photo can mean different things at different times and places. Today, artists use photographs in their work. Since Andy Warhol, artists have mixed photos with paintings. Photography is now an important part of art, not separate from it.

In 1890, William James, an American thinker and doctor, called psychology the "science of mental life." This idea is still useful today. We all have thoughts and feelings, so we have some idea of what this means. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is mostly about humans. James thought human psychology had basic parts: thoughts and feelings, the world around us, and how we know about these things. Our understanding is personal and comes from our own experiences. Sometimes, we think we know why people act a certain way, like feeling sad or quitting a job. But people can see things differently. Psychology tries to find out which explanations are correct. It helps us know the difference between our own ideas and scientific facts. 
Psychologists study the mind and brain, but they don't know everything about how the brain works. They learn more by watching how people behave and making guesses about what happens inside us. Studying psychology is hard because we can't see the mind like we can see an engine. We have to guess what is happening by looking at behavior. Psychology is like solving a puzzle. It uses clues from careful watching and measuring. Psychologists want to describe, understand, predict, and change things they study. This helps us understand our experiences and improve our lives. Psychology has helped in many areas, like teaching children to read better, making machines safer, and helping people talk about their feelings.
People have talked about psychology for a long time, but it has been studied scientifically for only about 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, which means thinking about their own thoughts, to find answers. But this method has limits. William James said trying to understand the mind this way is like trying to see in the dark by quickly turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to study what they can see, like how people behave, instead of just thinking about their own experiences.

In a simple building in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum has many products that people did not want to buy, like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. The museum is owned by a company called GfK. Carol Sherry, who runs the museum, thinks each product has a sad story about the people who made and sold it. 
The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who used to work in marketing, wanted to collect a library of new products. He began buying one of every new product he found starting in the 1960s. He did not plan to collect failed products, but most new products do not succeed. So, his collection became mostly products that failed.
Many people today are very optimistic, which might be why these products were made. People in meetings might not have realized the products would fail. Even if they did, they might have spent more money trying to sell them to save face. People often do not talk about why a product failed.
In the self-help world, people often use "positive visualization," which means imagining things going well. Some scientists, like Tali Sharot, say our brains are made to think things will go better than they might. This can help us survive, but it might not always help us succeed.
Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen found that thinking too much about success can make people less motivated to reach their goals. For example, people who imagined having a great week at work often did less.
Another psychologist, Carol Dweck, says how we think about ability affects how we handle failure. Some people think ability is fixed and cannot change. They find failure very upsetting. Others believe ability can grow with effort and see failure as a chance to learn. Dweck says this second way of thinking is better for happiness, even if it does not always lead to success.

Sports teams often do better when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know, but sports are changing a lot. Two things are making us question the old ideas about home advantage: science and money. 
Sports scientists want to know what helps players do their best. They have many ideas about home advantage. People who pay the players want to know if home advantage still matters. They think if players get enough money, they should play well anywhere.
Fans are important too. For example, if Manchester United played some home games in Asia, British fans might not like it. They think their team needs their support. Fans often believe that when they cheer, their team scores. But they forget the times when cheering did not help.
One thing that seems true is that home fans can affect the referee. In an experiment, referees watched a game with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees might avoid making the home crowd angry.
Studies show that home advantage is less now than before, but it still exists. In the 1890s, home teams in England won 70% of the time, now it's 60%. Travel is easier now, and stadiums are more similar, but home advantage is still a mystery.
Home advantage is different in each sport. It is strongest in basketball and football, but weakest in baseball. This might be because baseball is more about individual players, while basketball needs teamwork. Playing at home might make teams feel more confident.
Another reason for home advantage could be players' feelings. Before home games, players have higher testosterone levels, which might make them more aggressive. This was seen in the Rugby World Cup, where home teams won against stronger teams. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

"‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports. It means that practice makes you better, not really luckier. This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate: is talent something you are born with, or can you learn it? Many people believe practice is more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson said you can become an expert in anything with 10,000 hours of practice. This idea is in books like Outliers and Talent Is Overrated. They say practice is the most important thing. But David Epstein, in his book, says it is not always true. He shows that sometimes natural talent is also important. Epstein looks at why some people are very good at what they do. He travels to places like Kenya and Alaska to find answers. In Alaska, he learns that sled dogs' success might be because of their natural drive, not just training. This suggests that determination might also be genetic. Epstein talks about nature (what you are born with) and nurture (what you learn). He says both are important for top athletes. He also thinks about race and gender in sports. He asks why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the best."

A recent report says many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why children today feel this way. In her book, Kith, she says it's because children spend too much time indoors, watching TV or using computers, and not enough time outside in nature. She thinks this is the main problem. 
A study talked to children and found they would be happier if they could play outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their childhoods fondly, saying they had more freedom to play outside. They think this was healthier than how children live now. But these adults are the ones who keep their own children inside because they worry about safety.
Griffiths talks about how parents' fear of danger helps toy and gadget companies sell more products to keep kids busy indoors. She also mentions how some people give medicine to children who are restless or make them wear goggles for playground games. She thinks these rules are silly.
Griffiths believes children should have freedom to explore and take risks. She says children need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. But she doesn't explain how to make sure these accidents are small. She also wonders if all children want to be adventurous. Some children might prefer to stay at home and be quiet. Maybe the real problem is forcing all children to be the same, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of school. Most problems in life cannot be solved with formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My research focuses on how play helps children grow. All young animals, including humans, play. Animals that need to learn more, play more. For example, animals that hunt play more than those that eat plants. Primates, like monkeys, play more than other animals because they need to learn more. Children play the most because they have the most to learn. Play is how children learn important skills for life. These skills cannot be taught in school. They are learned through play. Skills like thinking creatively, getting along with others, and controlling emotions are important. Creativity is important for success. We need people who can solve new problems and ask new questions. Creative people think playfully. Geniuses keep their playful minds as they grow up. Albert Einstein said school almost made him lose interest in math and physics, but he found it again after school. He called his work 'combinatorial play'. He imagined chasing a sunbeam to develop his ideas. We cannot teach creativity, but we can stop it by focusing only on school questions. More important than creativity is getting along with others and working together. Children are born wanting to play with others. Through play, they learn social skills and fairness. Play is voluntary, meaning players can stop anytime. To keep playing, everyone must be happy. This makes play very fair. School has become harder: less break time, more homework, and more pressure for good grades. Outside school, adult-led sports have replaced free play. 'Play dates' with adults watching have replaced unsupervised play. Adults now feel they must solve children's problems. These changes have happened slowly but are big. They are caused by parents' fears, experts' warnings, less close neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children need more play, not more school. If we care about our children and the future, we must change this trend. We must let children play and explore so they can grow into strong adults ready for the future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn help them talk directly to employers. In the past, people had to do things like stand outside an office with a "hire me" sign to get noticed. But using social media can also lead to mistakes. 
For example, a young person in the US tried to connect with a marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts. The young person thought these contacts could help him get a job. But the executive was not happy. She did not want to share her contacts with someone she did not know. She sent a very rude message back, which many people saw online. People were shocked by her message. 
This story shows that using social media for jobs can be tricky. Many young people do not know how to use it correctly. Social media has been a big part of their lives for fun, but using it for work is different. When we were teenagers, social media was a place to have fun and be someone else. But for work, we need to be serious and professional.
